title: 112_hr1610
content: The "Business Risk Mitigation and Price Stabilization Act of 2011" may be cited as the Act. It includes margin rules. The Commodity Exchange Act is amended to address substantial net counterparty exposure in swaps that could impact the financial stability of the US banking system or financial markets. Margin requirements under the Act do not apply to certain counterparties. The margin requirements of this subsection do not apply to swaps involving counterparties that are not swap dealers, major swap participants, or certain types of investment funds. The Securities Exchange Act of 1934 is amended to exempt certain entities from margin requirements for swaps entered into before final rules are published under the Wall Street Transparency and Accountability Act of 2010. The Dodd-Frank Act amends margin requirements for security-based swaps to address potential risks to the financial system. Margin requirements do not apply to security-based swaps involving non-dealer counterparties. The Dodd-Frank Act amends margin requirements for security-based swaps to address risks to the financial system. Margin requirements do not apply to security-based swaps involving non-dealer counterparties, including entities not classified as security-based swap dealers or major participants, investment funds exempt under specific sections of the Investment Company Act, those primarily invested in physical assets like real estate, entities defined in the Federal Housing Enterprises Financial Safety and Soundness Act, or commodity pools. The Dodd-Frank Act amends margin requirements for security-based swaps to address risks to the financial system. Security-based swaps entered into before the final rules under the Wall Street Transparency and Accountability Act of 2010 are exempt from margin requirements. The amendments made by this section will take effect as if included in the Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act.
